Poem Title: TO THE MAN WITH A GUN
TO THE CHANCELLOR OF THE EXCHEQUER
line: TO THE CHANCELLOR OF THE EXCHEQUER

Poem Title: TO THE CHANCELLOR OF THE EXCHEQUER
TO THE CHANCELLOR OF THE EXCHEQUER

line: You may think it unkind of me
To interrupt the peaceful calm of your holiday
But I assure you, my dear sir,
That I do so with the very best intentions,
And at the call of what I consider to be duty.
Duty, as you know, is a tremendous abstraction,
And brings a man into all sorts of difficult corners.
It was duty that took you into Parliament:
Similarly it is duty that constrains me to Odes.
When a man sees another man and pities him,
It is the duty of the first man to let the other man know about it
I pity you, my dear Mr. Private Member,
From the bottom of a bottomless heart.
Many a time and oft in the course of my rambles
Through the lobbies and liquor bars of St. Stephens
It has been my ineffable portion to run across you--
Silk hat, frock coat, baggy trousers, patient stare, bored expression:
And crook the pregnant hinges of the back of your neck.
Mrs. Wiggle, the three Misses Wiggle, and little Master Wiggle,
Wife, daughters, and son of Mr. Forthree Wiggle,
Draper, and burgess of the good old Parliamentary Division
And they want showin' round the 'Ouse, you know.
Again: you appear in the Strangers' Lobby,
Spectacles on nose, somebody's card in hand.
The policeman roars out name of leading constituent.
Leading constituent departed in a huff twenty minutes ago,
Because he thought you were not attending to him.
Policeman roars out name of leading constituent once more.
But not being there, leading constituent fails to come forward.
You look embarrassed, turn tail, retire to your back bench,
And feel deucedly uncomfortable for the rest of the evening.
You would like to get away to the theatre,
But you dare not do it:
You would like to go home to bed;
You must wait the good pleasure of the course of the debate.
You would like to stand on your hind legs
And address the House on large matters:
But you know in your heart
That the House will stand absolutely nothing from you
You sit, and sit, and sit through dull debate after dull debate,
And you sigh for the hustings and the brass bands,
And wonder how it comes to pass
That you, who were once set down in the _Mudsher Mercury_
For a blend of Demosthenes and John Bright,
Can never get more than twenty words off the end of your tongue
Oh! my dear Mr. Private Member,
Your case is indeed a sad one,
And it is all the sadder when one comes to reflect
That, as a general rule, you are a sincereish sort of man,
Burning and bursting with a desire
To do your poor suffering country
You know that the men who have the ear of the House
That they are only "playing the party game,"
And that the country may go to pot for anything they care.
And yet they make their speeches
And get them reported at length in the papers,
And are given places in the Cabinet,
And go for "dines-and-sleeps" with the King,
What time you grow old and grey and obese and bleary eyed,
And never get the smallest show.
I pity you, my dear Mr. Private Member, I do really.
But for your comfort I may tell you
I am quite sure of it:
I wonder, my dear Sir, or Madam,
Why the Jews are so pleased:
Peace, my dear Sir, or Madam,
There was much shouting and yelling and roaring and squeaking
If the common or Regent Street growler
And, in reply to kind enquiries
But the spoils are to the victor.
They should have had a nice new ode,
But they have been and gone and lost,
In spite of your long and honourable connection
There appears to be something in you,
Which is more than can be said
You have won the bowt rice!
What is the good of winning the bowt rice,
Please do let me give it up.
You can afford to be generous;
Suffer me to indulge my little whim:
In winning the bowt rice, Cambridge
When I come to think of it
At the very least, it makes one safe
And what self-respecting person from Cambridge
I have heard of a man
And I have heard of another man
And is now driving a four-wheeler.
You see the difference, of course!
A sort of start in life,
Always remember, my dear Cambridge, who you are.
You licked Oxford by five lengths
This has been a great week
One of the biggest weeks in fact
For at the beginning of the week, my dear Mr. Leno,
You were a mere popular entertainer,
You are a proud and 'appy man,
And in a position to walk about the Strand
King Edward VII., D.G.: B. et T.T.B.R.: I.I.,
_Does_ intend to give artists and authors and people
A little bit more of a show
Than has hitherto fallen to their lot.
Has always been noted for his tact,
And in opening the ball with you, as it were,
His Majesty has exhibited an amount of tact
Which leaves absolutely nothing to be desired.
Had he commenced with Mr. Swinburne,
What howls there would have been!
And the Halls resound nightly with his Majesty's praises.
Has its basis in a profound common sense;
For I am acquainted with nobody in the movement,
Who could have done the Sandringham turn
With anything like the success which appears to have been yours.
That the King "laughed heartily" at your jokes,
And that "it was a treat to see him enjoying himself."
It is just here that Mr. Swinburne, myself, and Mr. Hall Caine
That the King would have laughed
My own jokes, as everybody is aware,
While, as for Mr. Hall Caine's jokes,
They have such a tremendous sale
That it is not good form to laugh at them.
You have been the humble means
When next it is my pleasurable duty
That hand which Royalty has shaken
That smile will cheer me all the more readily
But, after all, the great point
I suppose you would not care to lend it to me
I am inclined to think that I am those three men
Well, my dear Pope, I hear on all hands
That you are engaged, at the present moment,
In the cheerful act and process
And I know what pleasant little functions they are,
Sends a mission to congratulate one on them.
You must know, my dear Pope,
And in my own delightful country,
I am a rabid, saw-toothed Kensitite Protestant;
And, if they don't, they ought to.
Also, I never go into Smithfield
Without thinking of the far-famed fires thereof
And that the King defends the Faith.
But, when I get on to the Continent,
To do my week-end in Paris,
Or my "ten days at lovely Lucerne,"
Or my walk with Dr. Lunn
The bottom falls clean out of my Kensitariousness
And I become a decent, mass-hearing, candle-burning Catholic.
And may probably be accounted for
Here, in England, my dear Pope,
Whether we be Catholics or Protestants or Jews or Gentiles or
And we all see you, in our minds' eye,
Or walking in the Vatican Garden
We all think of you, my beloved Pope,
As a diaphanous and dear old gentleman
Whose intentions are the kindest in the world.
And yet, and yet, and yet--
So rages in our honest British blood
That, in spite of your white garments
We feel quite sure that you do carry,
And that, if certain people had their way,
You would soon be lighting such a candle in England
That we should want a new Foxe
And a new Book of Martyrs
Of about the size of a pantechnicon.
Hence it is, my dear Pope,
And make the King swear fearful oaths
Against popery and all its works,
Although, for aught one knows to the contrary,
He may have Mass said twice daily
Behind the curtain, as it were.
All the same, I wish you good wishes

line: I did not come to Dunkirk,
I did not come to Dunkirk,
I did not come to Dunkirk;
So that it was in vain, my dear Tsar,
That you and your Imperial spouse
(To whom I offer my very humble duty),
That you and your Imperial spouse
(To whom I again offer my very humble duty)
I was not on the poop,
I was not on the poop,
I was not on the poop,
I was not even abaft the binnacle,
In fine, I was not there at all.
The North Sea or German Ocean, my dear Tsar,
As, for example, a Dover-Ostend route.
I give you my word for it;
But the North Sea or German Ocean
And part of Monday morning last.
Had I of that Ostend-Dover route;
And I am now at a place called Thame
Though I promised a man at Bruges,
That I would infallibly see him
But you can explain for me,
Can you not, my dear Tsar?
The North Sea or German Ocean
That is precisely what it did to me.
I thank thee, Tsar, for that beautiful word fatigue.
All day Monday I felt so fatigued
That I went and joined a Peace Society.
The Boer war, my dear Tsar,
So far as I am concerned;
Henceforth I quarrel with no man.
Fatigue has laid its heavy hand upon me;
I am too much fatigued to quarrel even with the partner of my joys
Time writes no wrinkles on the Ostend-Dover route.
But you should see the people who have been that way.
It is now many happy weeks
Since I had the pleasure of addressing you.
On the last occasion, you will remember,
With a medal and sundry excellent stories
As to the manner in which you had been received
And the Members of the Royal Family.
"To see them laugh," you told us, "was a treat."
Since then you have gone about
With a diamond "E" in your cravat,
And "The King's Jester" written all over you
I do not doubt for a moment
That the King really did laugh
(That is to say, at Mr. Leno) myself,
And I know what it is;
It is my turn to laugh,
And I do so with a right good will,
Your cup appears to be full,
Inasmuch as for this day only
You are actually editing a paper!
Now when a man takes to editing papers
I have read your paper, Mr. Leno,
And I find that on the whole
It has been remarkably well edited:
That is to say, you as Editor
In the only way in which an editor
Namely, by leaving it to itself
If all editors would have the sense
Would, to say the least of it,
It seems in a way a pity, Mr. Leno,
When there are so many morning papers
Would have offered you a fair field
For the exercise of your extraordinary abilities;
Even the _Times_ might, for once in a way,
Is always (and still) on the look-out
Which somehow never comes its way.
And possibly it will not come round again.
As you are young in journalism,
Let me say three things to you:
It is better to be in the ballet;
Item, always be on either a morning paper or a weekly.
The all-day papers keep one too busy.
Item, if you are an editor only for a day,
Be sure to subscribe to the Newspaper Press Fund;
Otherwise, what will your widow do?
It is not my purpose to harp
Or to express the smallest satisfaction
Either with you as an official personage
Or with your verses as a production of an official personage;
I have called to-day, as it were,
You are a fellow-townsman of mine,
I am a fellow-townsman of yours;
We ought to get on well together.
Between ourselves, my dear Poet Laureate,
That if you were to set about it
You might, with very little trouble
Render a real service to the State
You have, if I may say so, chances and opportunities
Such as do not appear to have been vouchsafed
To any other contemporary worker in the department of Letters.
Our Gracious Sovereign Lord King Edward VII.
Continually consults you on matters literary
"Dear Mr. Austen" (I can hear him saying),
"Would you now advise me to read
Of course, my dear Poet Laureate,
If you were one of those stiff ungenerous Poets Laureate
Who make it a rule to stick to business,
But I am not your Majesty's Book-Taster,
Being, as your Majesty is aware,
Paid only to wangle my harp
In celebration of Births, Deaths, and Marriages.
Therefore I must respectfully, civilly, humbly, and generally otherwisely
Beg to decline to answer your Majesty's kind inquiry."
There is nothing of that sort about you.
You believe that a Poet Laureate,
Should not only be a sort of walking rhyming dictionary,
But also a general compendium of advice, counsel, and straight tips
That when his Majesty the King
_Does_ ask you for a hint as to the kind of book he ought to read
You break the marble box of your wisdom
Of an exceedingly amiable and capable Monarch,
To do what you can in that quarter
For the benefit of your brethren and sisters of the pen.
Many of them, my dear Poet Laureate,
With weary souls and tattered nerves
Have not been blessed and approved,
Some of them believe in their hearts
That they ought to have a peerage.
Others desire to be Baronets, Knights, and so forth,
In order that their wives may be called "Lady."
Would be well content with a humble K.C.B.
Would go off their heads with joy
If they might only be invited regularly
To the King's Levees and Droring Rooms.
I charge you to do your best for these suffering people.

Poem Title: IT SHOULD MOST CERTAINLY BE RECOGNISED BY THE CROWN.

line: Your own desires in the way of "recognition"
Are of course your own affair,
Ask for what you like, my dear Poet Laureate,
And see that you get it,
Peace hath her victories as well as war
When I have occasion to travel
In this muggy metropolis of ours,
I begin to wonder whether I really am in London,
On the tops of Atlas 'buses, and all other 'buses,
At the dining-tables of hotels at all prices,
You, my dear Sir or Madam
Flourish and are to the fore,
There are people in the world
Who can pick you out at a glance.
The American woman, I am told,
Wears a certain kind of complexion
And a certain kind of blouse;
The American man, I am told,
He has a soft hat and unlimited dollars:
It is his dollars, of course,
Which are creating all the trouble.
Wherever honest Britons most do congregate.
Who sells me two ounces of the real thing every week,
Has just been bought up by an American syndicate;
My barber is in the same case;
That the woman who brings home "the laundry"
Is seriously considering proposals which have been made to her
By a syndicate of wealthy American gentlemen.
The electric-lighting plant in St. Paul's Cathedral
Was, it seems, paid for by an American.
Another American is doing something or other
And a third proposes to erect a building
On one of the best sites
There are no flies on you.
How are Mr. Roosevelt and all at home?
Have you seen the Amur'can eagle at the Zoo?
And it's O to be at home
With one's money well invested in English concerns,
And paying good old, fruity, nourishing British dividends!
While still a youth and all unknown to fame,
I put on a beautiful blue jersey, and some striped knickers,
And betook myself into a damp field
With my hands nice and clean,
My shins had the appearance of a broken paint can,
My garments were covered with mud,
One of my teeth had somehow got swallowed,
And my hair was out of joint.
When I come to think of it,
In that hour I must have been a Muddied Oaf,
Though I did not know what to call myself.
And no doubt on that and successive Saturday afternoons
I won my various journalistic Waterloos,
And contracted a stubborn cardiac hypertrophy
Which is even yet with me.
I have never, to my knowledge,
Taken part in a football match;
And, in spite of Mr. Kipling,
I do not propose to indulge again
In either Rugby or the other thing.
In old age one flings one's mud at other people.
I don't know, my dear Muddied Oaf,
How you like being called a Muddied Oaf.
The average Muddied Oaf of my acquaintance
Will not in the least understand
And even when a dozen reporters
Have explained it to him, dictionary in hand,
You cannot take the glory of having crumpled up the Footleum Otspurs
It is a poor synonym for "dashing forward."
Phrases out of poems cannot damp your ardours.
And, so far as you are concerned,
All the same, I assure you
That there is a great deal in what the gentleman says.
To shoot out of a No. 1 rifle
At a choice array of clay pipes, dancing globules, and cardboard rabbits
Is on the face of it
You can do it with your hair parted:
And providing you don't get betting drinks
That you will ring the bell every time,
Will no doubt make a soldier and a gentleman of you,
And teach you to fear no Boer in shining armour.
Also, the game does not hurt.
You need no lemon to help you through with it,
You run no risk of dislocation, fracture, hypertrophy, gouged eye,
You are on velvet all the time.
And when it comes to calling names,
You will have the honour and glory
Of being set down for a gallant and gilt-edged
I have been taught to look upon a publisher
As a very great person indeed.
When I was young and courted him
He it was drew from me
Not to glorify with his imprimatur.
I looked upon publishing as a trade
And I feel in the heart of me
In spite of all that has been said to the contrary,
I have not had time to look him up,
That he was not a professional man.
Why did he not publish something?
I sometimes think I should like to be a publisher myself.
Mr. So-and-so, and Mr. So-and-so, and Mr. So-and-so
And how many "A second large edition"
It must be rather nice, also,
To go off to Switzerland every year
It must be rather nice, too,
That when an author is making money
And not infrequently a trifle more,
That when a publisher dies rich
He has made his money out of Apollinaris.
Are not by any means bad people,
And invariably take a kindly interest
That a publisher seldom goes bankrupt,
And does not as a rule sleep
I lent a publisher half a crown.
The average author would have taken it
I am inclined to like publishers,
And to set them down in my tablets
For oft in the stilly night
I have a horror of bankruptcy,
At any rate in my dreams.
And for public examination as it were,
And the presiding genius of the court
"To what do you attribute your financial rottenness?"
I fall into a colder sweat
I have been living at an hotel."
I come in for every sympathy:
The Court has been there itself;
There is not a dry eye about the place,
Every man present knows what I mean,
And his heart is touched accordingly.
You also know what I mean;
That I am the victim of a convention,
And that, when all is said that can be said,
You are the author of that convention.
As to the nature of that convention
We will put it this way:
In the way of potatoes and peas might cost, say, 6d.,
(You will notice that I put a princely price on everything),
Fifty per cent. profit for you, let us say,
Really you ought to let one off for 2s. 9d.,
So far as I can gather from your bills,
Whether you should charge one 3s. 6d. or 4s. 6d.
And you usually come to the conclusion
That you thought you were dealing with a gentleman.
You are quite correct in this surmise.
Especially in view of the fact
That the attendance wears dirty shirts,
Is lukewarm if you order it cold
And lukewarm if you order it hot;
And that the coffee before rising
That all this is very mean
Matters not so much to me
People come once to your establishment,
The next man that comes along
As much extra as he will stand,
Have a shilling bottle of wine

line: Who am always on the side of wisdom,
Have discovered a justification for you.
There has been a great demand of late
Mr. Kipling has started a village rifle club.
I understand that the members thereof
Are, let us say, five hundred in number.
Now, I put it to you, Sir,
Shooting in this beautiful country and Scotland
But you could make a fairly big rifle club out of them.
And of course all beautiful shots.
Will they answer to the call?
That to-day you are a hundred years old,
What nine men out of every ten of you
By taking a whole holiday instead of a half one.
It would be easy for me, my dear Stock Exchange,
With a sort of illuminated address on this occasion;
I tumbled into a little money;
It was "not enough to live upon,"
But it was a nice sum.
A man introduced me to a member of the Stock Exchange,
The member of the Stock Exchange introduced me to a little game
And my five hundred pounds folded its tents like the Arabs--
That is to say, it silently stole away.
It was not the member of the Stock Exchange's fault;
Certainly it was not my fault;
And I will not say that it was the fault of the Stock Exchange.
But I am not giving the Stock Exchange
On the other hand, let me assure you
That I believe the Stock Exchange
It leaves the court without a stain upon its character.
I say these latter things advisedly,
A friend of mine who writes articles on food supply
Having delivered himself of the opinion
That London's milk was largely water,
By the Amalgamated Society of Dairymen's Daughters,
And had to climb down and apologise.
So that on the whole I repeat that, in my humble opinion,
Men of spotless character and impregnable probity,
Than wend your way to Gorgonzola Hall.
And joking apart, my dear Stock Exchange,
If it were not for you
People with a lot of money,
And people with only a little,
It would lie in banks and old stockings and kindred receptacles
You are the heart of the monetary world,
You pump out all that you don't happen to want.
And you go and live in Maida Vale,
And change your name from Manassah to Howard.
Supposing, instead of taking a day,
You were to take a year,
In Fleet Street all is gay
From min' office window I catch glimpses
Of fluttering bunting and swinging festoons.
I don't know who pays for them
(The bunting and the festoons, that is to say),
But I am informed by the police that they
(The bunting and the festoons, that is to say)
Have been hung up in honour of YOU.
I am also given to understand that there has been a big rush
For free windows to view your procession,
Which, all being well (the Procession, that is to say)
Will take place this day, Saturday;
For my own part I am going into the country,
And I dare say that on the whole
You wish you were going with me;
And if you will become Lord Mayor of London
(A dizzy pinnacle to which none but the biggest-souled of us
I suppose you must put up with the attendant inconveniences
So far as I have been able to judge
(And I arrive at this conclusion by dint of steadfast abstinence
A Lord Mayor's Show is a distinctly inspiriting spectacle.
As the Londoner's one annual opportunity
Of seeing a circus for nothing;
Think not, however, my dear Lord Mayor,
That I deprecate your little pageant, gratis though it be.
Has for centuries past been on the high road to ruin,
And, in my humble opinion, its decadence has been largely due
To a deep-rooted tendency on the part of the powerful
To curtail and do away with mayoral and other shows.
Feasts and fairs have been kicked out of England
If you would be a respectable community
You must have neither feast nor fair,
And, if you would be a respectable citizen of any given city,
You must not array yourself in motley.
A man who walked into his bank
In yellow trousers and a blue silk hat
Would never be allowed an overdraft,
Black and subdued greens and browns being the only wear
For persons who would get on in life.
All this is wrong, my dear Lord Mayor.
I am of opinion that millionaires
I see no reason why I myself
Should not have a morning coat of red, white, and blue,
Or a waistcoat emblazoned with the arms
Of the Worshipful Company of Spectaclemakers.
In fact, my dear Lord Mayor,
The colour of life is the salt of it,
Just as the Lord Mayor's Show is the salt of the Lord Mayoralty
About life as people expect you to live it
Come hither, come hither, my dear Lord Mayor,
We are all glad to see you going up Fleet Street,
We are all glad to see you going home the other way;
And we shall be equally glad to see your successor
Getting through the same flowerful day's work
When men have nightmares, they dream about you.
I myself have been chased over the tops of pinnacles
To read reports of the proceedings of police courts
One finds that the average citizen
Gets more or less chased by you sir,
The Police I know, sir, seldom speak the truth:
They remember so well the day
When a horseless carriage had to be taken through the street
At the speed of a funeral march,
And with a red flag in front of it,
That the spectacle of an affable motorist
To the tune of six miles an hour
And they believe for the rest of their natural lives
At the rate of anything from 60 to 600 miles per minute.
It comes to pass that you are afforded so many opportunities
For airing your eloquence and the fatness of your purse
In my opinion it seems just possible
That the real trouble lies in the fact
That you, my dear sir, do actually
Go through villages at a very low speed,
And that really the best thing you can do
Would be to make a point of going through them
With the safety of your own person.
No policeman of my acquaintance would be able to catch you,
Hence you would never be fined.
I have been out of sympathy with motor cars
Right up to the other night.
The other night I had the felicity to take a small trip on one.
The motorist would fain have driven me to my house,
Which is half an hour's cab drive from Charing Cross.
He offered to do the distance in ten minutes
And started stirring up his petroleum,
But I said "No.  Let us go to the Marble Arch."
We went through the Mall, to Hyde Park Corner,
Into the Edgware Road, and so to the Marble Arch;
That we went down certain streets quite rapidly,
What time the policemen at odd corners stared stupidly,
But, as a result of that trip, my dear sir,
I have become an enthusiastic motorist.
I am convinced that speed and wind and the smell of petroleum mixed
Is the only thing which can be considered worth living for.
And if you happen to know anybody
Who would be willing to take
A typewriter and a pair of skates (not much worn)
In exchange for a Durkopp racer,
It is an excellent journalistic thing,
Not to say a poetical thing,
To be first in the field.
At the head of that motley army
He came in with several thousand inches of rain;
He went out on a watery moon.
Half the world pretended to be happy,
The other half pretended to be bored.
There is a ping-pong tournament at the Queen's Hall
At the Guildhall on Tuesday evening;
Not to mention Mr. Dan Leno at Drury Lane
And Mr. De Wet at the Tweefontein.
Christmas comes but once a year,
And it will come again, I fear.
For I never miss an opportunity
When the way is plain before me.
Come next year by all means;
You would come just the same.
And I trust, my dear Next Christmas,
You will bring us a little luck.
Ring out the old, as it were,
To the satisfaction of both parties;
Let there be a fine Christmas Eve
And a little skating next morning;
Let there be peace and plenty,
And a barrel full of beer,
Including a free and enlightened Press,
Otherwise he would have let his kettle boil
Omitted to take cognisance of the ultimate trouble,
And here, alas! you will stay,
Till our iron roads are beaten into ploughshares,
And Messrs. Cook & Sons are at rest.
"When I was young, a single man,
(Which, strange as it may seem, is Wordsworth)
Your goings to and fro upon the earth,
And walkings up and down thereon,
Were limited by the day trip.
Were put on for your delectation;
You sang a mixture of hymns
And there was an end of the matter.
But nowadays there is no escape from you.
The trip that was over and done
Of "Saturday to Monday at Sunny Saltburn,"
And "A Visit to the Holy Land for Ten Guineas."
Your empty ginger-beer bottle and your old newspaper;
Which you once reserved for noblemen's seats
Are now extended to the Rigi,
Indeed, I question whether it would be possible
Or "the dreary tundras of remote Siberia,"
Into such an uncompromising fastness as Craig Ell Achaie
(Which is the last place the Canadian Pacific Railway made
And which may not be properly spelled)
And prepared to greet all and sundry
And poets fill their columns easily,
So that I must not abuse you any more.
You are part of the Cosmos,
And as such I am bound to respect you;
For years past, Glasgow has stood in the forefront
As a city given over to the small-pox
In fact, it appears to be managed
Hence, no doubt, it comes to pass
By a smart sample of the plague.
I have not the smallest doubt that your Worships
I believe that you do what you do do, so to speak,
And with a view to bettering the condition
Of the city over which you preside.
In other words, I impute no motives:
That is to say, no base motives.
Why, in the name of Heaven, would you abolish
Have you never known the tender delight
With your elbow on the zinc
And threepennyworth of Bass before you?
What, may I ask your Worships,
I grant that, taking them all in all,
Are not what you might term
Years ago, when I was young and callow,
Fate threw me into the propinquity
Of a lady of this ilk;
On the other hand, I was young.
And, out of an income which was even slenderer then
I purchased for that dear lady of the North
And a Prayer Book or so;
And, when I had consumed innumerable Basses
And the time had, as I thought, become ripe,
To which she replied, in limpid Doric:
If you can weed out of Glasgow
Possessed of this particular kind of temperament,
But that you would have my blessing.
On the other hand, I am free to admit
That I hae my doots as to your capacity for so doing.
If I know anything of them.
That, if the magistrates of all the cities
Would take the step you have taken,
We should have gone a very considerable way
Into a fearful hole for money.
But I sometimes think that Scotch women
That this is a geographical fact.
In order that you may perceive
With the higher walks of Literature,
Of entirely different build from yourself.
And have stuck to my trade
Possibly you were born a bookseller.
I am willing to give your credit for it,
But I doubt it all the same,
For I often think the average bookseller
Must have been born a draper.
The other day I had occasion to do a little book-buying.
In what I now believe to be
An altogether elegant and delightful form
Of course, I went into a shop:
From the yawning Cimmerianity at the back of that shop
There came unto me swiftly and in large boots
He bowed, and he bowed, and he bowed.
"I want a good edition of Shelley," I said.
Whereat he smiled and banged under my nose
The best line in the market,
And looked disconsolately at the stodgy running-titles
He cast upon me eyes of contempt and disgust,
And told me that I could not expect
When I reflect that whatever I may write,
No matter how excellent it may be,
Must ultimately pass into the hands
The spirit of my fathers quails within me,
And next time I call upon you
As you appear to sell "Temporal Power."
(The wife of my bosom being still happily amongst us,
And I would not marry you
To save myself from boiling oil.
I could have had you in the beginning.
And if I had married you
Would have been aunt to her own children, as it were.
And in the event of your demise
Which is at once inconsequential and peculiar.
A man cannot marry his deceased wife's sister
Anyway, we will close this parenthesis
And proceed along the primrose path
(By "she" of course I mean the man's wife.)
That he cannot marry her anyhow
I desire to be explicit on these points
In order that we may avoid
Well, my dear deceased wife's sister
(Always remembering that Mrs. ---- is still alive),
What is your view of matters?
Do you really wish to marry me or not?
Have you any opinions about Lord Hugh Cecil?
Was he or was he not justified in demanding
Do not let us get confused.
Let us clear our minds of Cecil.
You are the Auntie of my children,
And the great-niece of my wife's great-uncle,
Not to say the sister-in-law of my children's father.
Let us get married at once.
Of course it is so sudden.
And we have forgotten about Mrs. ----
But I tell you here and now,
That if I wish to marry
Either you or any more of your mother's daughters
I shall go to Canada or Australia

line: And all the crowned heads of Europe,
Not to mention all the fat persons who desire to bant,
All the thin persons who desire to become
Vigorous and muscular, as it were,
All the clerks who desire to pass for dukes,
And all the dukes who relish the society of clerks.
The people who play it are not the fault of the game.
It is also a good game.
It is a game that originally came out of Scotland;
Therefore it must be a good game.
For everything that comes out of Scotland is good,
And golf being a great and good game
I do not see any tremendous reason
Why you, my dear Common Golfer,
Should not engage in it if you so choose.
On the other hand, I wish from the bottom of my heart
That you did not engage in it.
Oft of a pleasant summer morn
Have I taken a cheap ticket
To a station which is not far from that bank,
And there (on the bank, that is to say) reclined me
What time I looked up into the blue dome,
And wished my name was Corydon,
Oft, I say, have I done these things;
But of late I no longer do them,
Has become (if I may so term it)
The other day I repaired to the said bank
Why, my dear old thymy bank
Of half a dozen gross fellows in red coats,
Thy had pipes in their mouths,
And a jar of beer in their midst,
And they were actually talking and laughing
I heard one of them say
And trifled with their brassies and things,
You are always of such parties,
And depleting village public-houses of good beer,
And turning whole village populations into caddies,
And dotting the landscape with your red coats,
And generally appropriating the fair face of Nature.
I cannot stop you, my dear Common Golfer,
Would that I could.  O would that I could!
In which case, perhaps, I wouldn't.
Take them, old man, take them;
I hand them over to you with the best heart in the world.
I hasten to give you a hearty British welcome.
I am in the Trust line myself--
That is to say, I used to be
Before people started putting up announcements
Some day, an I mistake not, Mr. Morgan,
I am a political economist, and I know.
Meanwhile I am very pleased to think
That we have amongst us a man of your financial prowess
There is a certain class of British person
Who apparently goes in bodily fear of you.
That class of person has groaned loudly over your steel exploit,
And he has groaned loudlier still
Over your purchase of the Leyland Line of Steamships.
To groan over a fair deal of any kind
Appears to me, my dear Mr. Pierpont Morgan,
To be an entirely stupid proceeding.
Nobody can come to grief by selling things,
Providing they sell them at the right price.
You have bought the Leyland Line of Steamships:
I see no reason why you should not buy all the other lines
If you want them, and have the wherewithal to pay for them,
For in the long run everything comes to him who vends.
You buy my steamships, or my steelworks,
Or, for that matter, my caller herrin':
I take your money, I put it in your bank,
And live sumptuously on the interest.
Inasmuch as you have to rake up the interest.
I sit at home and enjoy myself,
You scheme, and scheme, and scheme, and scheme, and scheme,
Between ourselves I should not tremble
If you bought up Great Britain and Ireland (especially Ireland),
And all that in them is,
Providing always, as I have said before,
Indeed, I hope to live to see the day
When Englishmen will cease to toil and spin,
Wholly and solely from American dividends.
Fools buy things, my dear Mr. Pierpont Morgan,
When the article involved happens to be poetry.
Nevertheless, as you appear to be in a buying frame of mind,
I take this opportunity of informing you
That I have at my villa at Hindhead
Of sonnets, odes, rhymes, jingles, and what not,
Which I am prepared to sell at an enormous sacrifice.
My price to you for the lot would be
If you care to deal, I undertake to melt your cheque
And to invest the proceeds in any concerns
In which you happen to be interested,
So that you would not only get the poetry,
But also your money back again.
This, at any rate, is how it seems to me.
Who will one day be the Sovereign Lord
Of my loyalty to the Imperial House
Of which you are the joy and hope,
And of my respect for your own podgy little person.
To-day, I need scarcely tell you, my dear little Prince,
Is a very big day for you,
The Duke and Duchess of Cornwall and York, KG.--
Laden, I am given to understand,
With presents for his Royal Highness
Who, I am given to understand,
Has been a very good boy
During these long weeks of separation.
Will be able to give your parents a very good account of you,
With that tact which is only one of many of his excellent qualities,
Which might lead to parental chastisement,
That when my own Mama and Papa
Returned once from a little jaunt
A tin cylinder with a spike to it,
Which you set on a piece of wood
Then you looked through some holes in the tin cylinder
Such as a little girl skipping,
And jockeys riding a steeplechase on tigers.
If your Papa, my dear little Prince,
Has not brought you one of those,
Be sure you ask for it.
It is not rude to ask for what you do not see in the window,
Let me add a few words
I hope you will grow up to be a good and great man,
And that you will never give your parents
Or attempting to imitate these Odes.
May appear to be the most innocent in the world,
Diplomats, Members of Parliament, publishers' assistants,
Cabmen, poets, peers of the realm,
Nay, even the very crowned heads of Europe,
Been consumed with a desire to do them for me;
The easy thing is not always the wisest thing.
I feel that in my inmost heart.
And if you blossom into manhood
That you will be an immense success
I wish you the best of luck.
I have been very nigh addressing this ode
To the winner of the Derby.
But, on second thoughts, I said,
"Not while we have in our midst
Should return to her interesting country
Possessed of the impression that the _bas Anglais_
Have a greater feeling for _le sport_
_La patrie, la patrie, la patrie_, you know:
It is a fine country when you understand it,
And I would have my beautiful Bernhardt
Nothing but splendid memories of it.
To read in the papers the other morning
That in the opinion of the _critics dramatiques Anglais_,
At the Lyceum Theatre the other evening.
Wherein the eaglet is borne away
On a flight of adoration for the dead eagle,
They are, in fact, its keynote,
The famous voice has lost its golden notes,
But its power to thrill remains,
She runs the gamut of the emotions
With all the grace and dexterity
You have all the grace and dexterity
O crown and fulfilment of a life-time devoted to Ar-rt!
And in conclusion, my dear Mme. Bernhardt,
Will you do me the honour to allow me to explain
That in the event of any young enthusiast from Paris
Calling round at any of our newspaper offices
With a view to getting satisfaction
From the person who accuses you
Of having all the skill and dexterity
Because in my dear country, dear Madame Bernhardt,
We do not fight the duel _à la cut finger_,
(I have not time to get up your other distinguished names,
So that you must please excuse the plain Sir William),
My dear Sir William, do you ever survey the Liberal party,
And from Rosebery to Lloyd-George as it were?
Do you, my dear Sir William?  O do you?
I do, Sir William, I do indeed.
And what is the conclusion I come to, my dear Sir William,
What, what, what, what, what, what, what, what, what?
Shall I tell you, my dear Sir William?
You are sure you won't be offended if I do?
And it will be strictly between ourselves, now, won't it?
Put your sweet hand in mine and trust in me,
And do not construe my kindness into cruelty;
Harken, my dear Sir William, harken,
The Liberal party is an unweeded garden
Choked with a myriad strange growths,
And a sad, fierce, baffled, careless-ordered thing to look upon,
And in its midst there sits down perennially
A huge and ponderous and unwieldy ruminant,
Whom, merely for the sake of talking, my dear Sir William,
Here, when it is not at its lordly pleasure-house,
The Harcourt, as I say, sits down.
Goodman Bannerman cometh to his Liberal Garden
To gather him a posy and do a little weeding;
The Harcourt is there heavily chewing the cud,
And it takes the heart out of goodman Bannerman
Goodman Asquith had fain pick a bit of dinner in the precincts;
The Harcourt watcheth him with rolling eye,
And by and by cometh the simple, rural Rosebery,
He looks over the wall and sayeth,
"Gadzooks, when folk tell me that I am the man to put this
They speak a mortal deal o' truth.
I will e'en go in and delve a bit."
And then he beholdeth the Harcourt
Luxuriating with his back against the biggest fig tree,
That powerful big animal be there still,
And I know'un, I do, I know'un!"
What jobbing gardener of any self-respect
Would undertake to do up my genariums and fuchers
If I had a wild rhinoceros gambolling upon them
In finding such a jobbing gardener, my dear Sir William;
And, to come at once to the plain poetry so belovèd of this age,
Let me tell you, my dear Sir William,
That, in my opinion, you (and no other) are at the present juncture
The real trouble and incubus of the party you love.
If you would only go home and crown yourself with a laurel or two,
And read history books, and take tea with bishops
Would begin to get along like a house afire.
Will you not try it, my dear Sir William; oh, will you not try it?
For who would fardels bear and flounder round,
When he might sit with Lulu on the lawn
And leave his party for his party's good?
Possibly your name is not Brindle,
But that is of no consequence;
The great point, my dear Brindle, being
That when his Majesty Edward VII.
Landed at Flushing the other day
At least so I gather from the halfpenny papers,
And I am free to admit
That when I read the paragraph
Descriptive of your landing at Flushing
My bosom swelled with honest pride.
I am not a doggy man myself,
When I see a dog coming towards me
Is apt to stand on end
Like quills upon the fretful porcupine
At pretty well every canine approach.
So that I can well understand
To scoff in his sleeve at the English King,
Remained to flee as it were
To which previous reference has been made.
It was a picturesque circumstance, my dear Brindle.
To do things as a king of England should.
Would have been a little outré,
Why he takes, as he always has taken,
Next to the Lion and the Unicorn
The Bulldog is not too beautiful,
He fears no foe in shining armour,
Or any other sort of armour--
And he is kept by Lord Charles Beresford,
The genius of the British nation,
Which, for the sake of talking,
There are people in the world
In the time of your infancy,
Gave you the usual three months.
Get three months on the day of their birth.
For at the sight of a new sheet,
Your wise man invariably taps his nose,
Looks even wiser than is his wont,
You have survived the sentence of the wise,
And I am given to understand
That you have long been a tremendous property.
(Pray excuse me if I appear to say "but" again)--
Well, you know what I mean, don't you?
Let me put it this way.
When I come to town of a morning,
Not to put too fine a point upon it,
I see a row of silk or straw hats
(According to the state of the weather),
And between the hats and the trouserings
A row of rustling morning papers.
I can tell you the names of those papers
Five out of six of them is called
It is all right for you, of course,
And I do not like being distressed.
Now, why does it distress me?
Are you sure that you could bear the blow?
Can you pull yourself together for a moment?
The price of you is one halfpenny.
That in the present condition of the general purse,
Things which are sold for a halfpenny
I will give you my reasons some other day.
When I look into your pages,
I will be frank for the second time,
Writ in every line of you,
With its "Massa, me nebber leab you
While you keep So-and-So's toffee about,"
Of course there is no harm in that,
And far be it from me
I have no advice to offer you,
As I do not see how you can help yourself.
But I shall ask you kindly to note
Expressed at the beginning of this poem
Bear reference to your attainment of your 1,650th number
While you certainly have the right upon your side,
You appear to me to be conducting
The other day I lunched at a place
Where there was a pretty lady.
During the course of the talk
The pretty lady said to me,
"You see, Everybody is out of town
But don't you think it is rather
Fortunate that Everybody is out of town?
And the pretty lady answered and said,
Must, on the whole, be rather nice.
For Everybody should be rather nice,
And when I come to think of it
The circumstance that I heard of you
Has nothing prodigiously unusual about it.
One is always hearing about you.
For example, the paragraph writers assure me
Also, that Everybody will join with them
In congratulating Miss So-and-So on her approaching marriage;
Also, that Everybody is in the Highlands,
That Everybody anticipates a good season,
That Everybody sups at the Carlton after the theatre,
That Everybody recognises in Lord Salisbury a great statesman,
That Everybody who can afford it dresses well,
That Everybody knows the King has tact,
That Everybody thinks the Queen grows younger as she grows older,
That Everybody hopes Sir Thomas Lipton
I don't mind in the least.
I imagine that I should not do things
Quite in the same way that you do them.
To my mind, your great defect is that you do things
Not because you like to do them,
But to me it seems a trifle stupid.
Who is reading Miss So-and-So's book?
Do they like Miss So-and-So's book?
But Everybody says it is good,
And therefore Everybody must read it.
Why does Everybody dine at a certain restaurant?
Did time allow I might multiply instances
Enough, you know, is as good as a feast;
Wherefore I am constrained to believe it.
By way of conclusion, let us ask ourselves
That nothing is happening just now,
And that everything is frightfully dull;

Poem Title: UNWIN BROTHERS, LIMITED, THE GRESHAM PRESS, WOKING AND LONDON.
